messages.subject: Re: How can we bring America's conformity epidemic to a screeching halt?
messages.msgSnippet: I am reading Barbara Sher s book, It s only too late if you don t start now .  She talks about this at length.  I found the first half rather dull and skimmed
messages.messageBody:
I am reading Barbara Sher's book, "It's only too late if you don't start
now". She talks about this at length. I found the first half rather
dull and skimmed most of it, but the book gets really good in part two.
Mary Ellen
One can never have too many buttons.
Laurella Lederer

On 26 Jan 2000 17:56:06 -0800 "John O. Andersen" <andersen@...>
writes:
> Perhaps we could brainstorm about ways we can make this happen.
> Sure,
> modeling a life of individualized and heart-inspired dreams and
> noncompliance in things like rampant consumerism are the mainstay
> tactics.
> But are there other actions we might take to sabotage the forces
> which
> systematically turn fully alive human beings into conforming zombies?

messages.subject: How can we bring America's conformity epidemic to a screeching halt?
messages.msgSnippet: Perhaps we could brainstorm about ways we can make this happen.  Sure, modeling a life of individualized and heart-inspired dreams and noncompliance in things
messages.messageBody:
Perhaps we could brainstorm about ways we can make this happen. Sure,
modeling a life of individualized and heart-inspired dreams and
noncompliance in things like rampant consumerism are the mainstay tactics.
But are there other actions we might take to sabotage the forces which
systematically turn fully alive human beings into conforming zombies?

John O. Andersen
http://members.xoom.com/joandersen

"Only dead fish go with the flow." Anon.
